Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta is from the village of Manamong, Aloran, Misamis Occidental 7209. She is 60 years old, widowed and has 5 adult children. Benedicta is involved in  the agricultural sector, in particular farming. She has been engaged in her business for more than 25 years and earns approximately 5,000  pesos (PHP) a month.

In February 15, 2007 Annaliza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business.

Benedicta is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to provide working capital for her farming business

loans.name: Keo's Group

texts.en:
This village loan includes eight members. They are located in Ruessei Chrouy village in Kandal province. This village group selected, Mrs. Keo K., a 28 year old married woman, as the village bank president. They will each use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Keo K. and her husband, Mr. Chin Chanthy, are grocery and soup sellers in the local village. With these businesses, they still earn a small income with which to support their famiL.. As the grocery business is still generating onL. a meager income, Mrs. Keo K. would like to expand her store. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries and more food supplies.
  
This couple has two children: one is attending the local school and the other is just 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to expand her current business.

loans.name: Tauch

texts.en: The man shown in the picture above, Mr. Tauch K., is a 66-year-old farmer residing in the rural area of Kompong Cham Province. He and his wife have been cultivating crops for over ten years ago. They grow their rice crop on their own farmland, which they inherited from their grandparents. This couple has four children, two of whom are single, and the other two are married. One of them is working in the factory as a worker, and has a fixed salary. Dry weather is expected in the beginning of this year, and it may affect Mr. Tauch K.’s business. He faces a difficult season if he is not able to irrigate his crops. Mr. Tauch K. is taking out his loan to purchase a machine that he will use to pump water for his crops.

loans.use: To purchase a machine that he will use to pump water for his crops.

loans.name: Váng

texts.en:
Mrs. Váng K. is 50 years old and she is a villager who lives in Thum village in Kandal province. She is a pork seller in the local market, from which she is able to earn a small income to support her family. Aside from being a butcher in the local market, she also owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice for a living. With the farming effort, she doesn’t have enough money to cultivate. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for cultivating rice. 

Mrs. Váng K. is widow with two children: one is a motorbike repairer and the other is student in a local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides for cultivating rice.

loans.name: Meach

texts.en:
Mr. Meach S. is 63 years old, and he is a villager living in Ampil village, Kandal province. He and his wife are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate rice for a living. With the farm, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to cultivate it. So Mr. Meach S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizers and gasoline for cultivating the rice crop. 

Mr. S. is farmer who works very hard to support their three children: Two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the last one is a student. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers and gasoline for cultivating rice.

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en: Lonh H. is a 31-year-old farmer and mother. She was blessed with four kids, most of whom are attending school. Her husband, Hun Voeurn, is 50 and works in the farming business. Lonh H. inherited farmland from her grandmother. She and her husband grow different kinds of crops. For additional income for helping the whole family, Lonh H.’s husband is good at climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very popular for poor people who live in the commune. He is earning revenue in average $2.5 per day. Currently, Lonh H. will use her loan to help her husband’s business because some materials of climbing are getting old. In order to clear this problem, Lonh H. will use her loan towards for her husband to buy a few bamboo containers for sugar palm juice, a frying pan, and a ladder for her business.

loans.use: To buy a few bamboo containers for sugar palm juice, frying pan, and a ladder for her business.

loans.name: Hermilita

texts.en:
Hermilita is persistent in working towards her dream of making her doormat-making business more profitable. Despite having difficulty maintaining her business, Hermilita is hopeful that someday her dream will land in the palm of her hand. She cannot reinvest her profits into her business as it is also the main source of her family's daily expenditures. To make her dream happen, Hermilita wants to request a much larger loan to support the needs of her business and at the same time to sustain its operation. 

With her great passion for giving her children a better future and decent way of life, she will be willing to work hard and supplement her husband’s irregular income.

As a loving mother, Hermilita’s dreams are always for her three children and family. She wants to bring her children a higher quality of life, out of poverty. In 2006, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She hopes to secure access to capital for the continuation of her business. Her previous loans were carefully used as additional and rolling capital for her doormat-making business. 

Hermilita is hopeful that her business will grow and that someday she will have more customers around the village. She also dreams of sending all her children to school until college so that they can get better jobs.

loans.use: To support the needs of her business and at the same time to sustain its operation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy beauty products.

loans.name: María Narcisa

texts.es: María Narcisa F. D. D. D. 59 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. San Vicente, en donD. se dedica a la venta D. zapatos y F.. Ella vive únicamente junto a su madre D. 89 años D. edad, por quien trabaja muy duro para que cuente con todo lo necesario. María se dedica a la venta ambulante D. zapatos, los cuales comercializa por mercados y plazas, D. esta misma manera coloca los zapatos sobre la calle principal que lleva al mercado regional D. San Vicente, en donD. cuenta con muchos clientes, así mismo comercializa F. por mayor las cuales venD. en su casa D. habitación. Ella es una persona muy trabajadora, quien se esfuerza en gran manera para salir adelante, es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo a Integral para poder comprar mayor cantidad D. F., y zapatos para hombres, mujeres y niños. Para María mejorar sus ganancias es D. mucha importancia debido a que es gracias a estas como posee todo lo necesario para vivir dignamente.
texts.en:
María Narcisa F. D. D., 59, lives in San Vicente department where she sells shoes and flowers.  She lives just with her 89 year old mother for whom she works very hard so that she will have everything she needs.

María has been a street vendor of shoes at various markets and squares.  She spreads out the shoes on the sidewalk along the main avenue that leads to the San Vicente regional market.  She has many customers.  She also sells flowers at wholesale from home.

She is a very hard working person who tries very hard to get ahead.  For this reason she is asking Integral for a loan to buy larger amounts of flowers and shoes for men, women and children.  For María improving her profits is very important because it’s thanks to them that she has everything necessary to live in a dignified manner.

loans.use: To buy shoes and flowers to sell.

loans.name: Vit

texts.en:
Vit K., age 21, is married to Kheng Khoun, age 29. She has two children, both of whom are single, and still living under her control. Vit K. has a plot of farm land for growing rice in both the rainy and dry seasons. Her husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees in and around his house. The two of them share in the responsibility of the family. She and her husband have earned a better income since her first two children grew up and went to work. 

Vit K. is looking for a loan in order to support her husband's business to purchase additional equipment for operating his palm-climbing business such as flying pan, and bamboo container for sugar palm juice. Vit K. and her husband are pictured in photo.

loans.use: To buy flying pan, and bamboo containers for sugar palm juice

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs.Sim C. is a 50-year-old married woman and a local villager living in Kompong Cham Province. She and her husband are local farmers. This couple is blessed with three children, two are single and one is married. Sim owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She planted rice and vegetable crops two months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy some fertilizer. She will use the remainder of the loan to buy some seed for additional planting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed for additional planting

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Khim K., 43, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. All of her children are single; two of them are working in different jobs. Khim K. inherited farmland from her grandmother and she grows different kinds of crops, such as rice and vegetables on her farmland. Her husband is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few employees to help him provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. The main income in this family comes from her husband’s business. Khim K. would like to request a loan from Kiva to help her husband purchase construction equipment for his building service.

loans.use: To purchase construction equipment

loans.name: Burmagul's Group

texts.en:
Burmagul S., 36, is the leader of this group. Five years ago she decided to make a contribution to the family budget by opening a small grocery shop. Her husband supported her morally and financially, believing that it would help them to raise two sons, 14 and 1 years old. Burmagul’s husband is a construction worker, and makes 10,000 KGS a month. With today’s conditions of rising prices and expenses, Burmagul decided to advance her business to increase her profit. 

The family business worked out well, and they managed to buy a house. Now Burmagul would like to get a loan to diversify the assortment of goods she sells. She believes her business will be a success and she’ll be able to repay the loan.

The small town of Tashkomur in southern Kyrgyzstan has been well known for its coal reserves. But after the fall of Soviet Union, it has been shut down. Mining factories have been closed, and the town has been struggling to survive. Many just immigrated to Russia and Kazakhstan, some stayed searching for new ways to make ends meet. The men usually do construction jobs, while women are involved in sales activities in local bazaars and markets. Burmagul’s story is an example of a typical Tashkomur family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff for sale

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en:
All experiences in life do not happen in vain. A person can learn lessons from every little thing that has happened to them. For many people, harsh life conditions are not an excuse to give up and stop trying. People like that find inspiration and are inspired themselves by others. Our next client is a bright example of this type of person. 

Dinara K., 22, is a resident of the small town of Kerben. She is the leader of this group. A mother of three boys, she and her husband work in cattle in the Aksy region. Their monthly income is 8,000 KGS. Dinara hopes to get a loan to broaden her business and contribute to her family’s living standard. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Masudakhan's Group

texts.en:
Masudakhan B., 47, is the leader of this group. She has raised cattle since childhood. Being very experienced, she has already acquired 27 sheep and 24 goats. She is a mother of two sons, 27 and 19. She is a proud veteran of cattle breeding for 20 years. For her business start-up, she spent 8,000 KGS. She has applied for this loan to improve the living conditions of her cattle and to buy fodder. Masudakhan thanks all lenders for making attempts to change her life. 

Kyrgyzstan's principal exports, which go overwhelmingly to other CIS countries, are non-ferrous metals and minerals, woolen goods and other agricultural products, electric energy, and certain engineering goods. In turn, the Republic relies on other former Soviet states for petroleum and natural gas, ferrous metals, chemicals, most machinery, wood and paper products, some foods, and most construction materials.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fodder

loans.name: Buenaventura

texts.en:
Buenaventura T. is from the town of Trinidad. He is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Buenaventura owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Buenaventura also owns and tills a rice farm. He sells his harvest to the market.

Buenaventura joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Buenaventura has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Buenaventura is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Miraida's Group

texts.en:
Coal has been a very important part of energy sources in Kyrgyzstan. The government is planning to increase the mining of coal, in order to decrease the dependence on imported oil and gas from other countries. However the small output does not meet domestic needs. 

Miraida R., 22, is a resident of a small coal mining town, Tashkomur. She has raised and sold cattle for almost two years. Despite the fact that she’s only 22 years old, Miraida makes good use of her business. Her husband is a coal miner. The family used his salary to purchase 4 sheep in 2008. They say the biggest challenge was starting the business, but later they became accustomed to the business atmosphere. The monthly proceeds from business is only 7,000 soms. This amount is far from their wishes. In the future the they plan a larger family and to create good conditions for their children. Miraida would like to get a loan to purchase 5 more livestock animals for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en:
Restituta R. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has 8 children. Her eldest child is 27 years old while the youngest is only 6 years old. Five of her children are still in school and Restituta works hard to sustain their education.

To make a living, Restituta owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Restituta has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Restituta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is a 57-year-old who is married with four children.  She lives in the province of Antipolo, Rizal, in the Philippines with her husband.  For almost six years, Editha has been engaged in hog fattening.  She is hard-working, determined, and dedicated.  She would like to receive a loan to purchase additional piglets, feed, vitamins, and other supplies.

Editha has been a very active member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2005. She has been a model member, demonstrating regular attendance to weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.  

Because of poverty, her four children attained only a low level of education. She won’t let this happen to her grandchildren. Now, with the help of ASHI, Editha has already helped fund her grandchildren's education, and hopes to continue until they complete college. 

Editha’s dreams are for her four children to experience lives full of happiness.  Additionally, she hopes to continue her hog fattening business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family, to reach her goals in life, and to have a happy family.

Editha is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for offering financial support for her business dreams.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feed, vitamins and other supplies.

loans.name: Nazik

texts.en:
Nazik G. was born in Yerevan in 1968. She is married and has a son and a daughter. Her husband works in an ice-cream factory. At present, her son is in the army, protecting the Armenian state boarder. Her daughter is a student. For 10 years Nazik has been engaged inthis business. Nazik rents a stall in a trade center in Yerevan, near her house, where she resells fruits and vegetables, which she buys from the Malatia food market. Nazik is  very lively person. She works very hard and thanks to that she has a large quantity of clients who are glad to do their shopping from Nazik's stall. The profits from the sales allow her to take care of the needs of her family, support her son's needs in army and pay for daughter education. 

Nazik has requested a 400.000 AMD loan to increase the fruits and vegetables assortment in her stall in advance of New Year’s holidays, when the trade is very active
	
This is Nazik’s second loan from Kiva and Nor Horizon.

loans.use: To increase the fruit and vegetable assortment in her stall in advance of New Year’s holidays

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.en:
Teofilo H. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 51 years old. Teofilo is married and has 10 children. To make a living, Teofilo owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating "habal-habal" (motorcycle) services. Teofilo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

Teofilo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teofilo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Teofilo is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family financially.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.en:
Primitiva is from the village of Lawa-an, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Primitiva is married and has four children. To make a living, she is involved in a business of buying and re-selling a variety of products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately $70 a month from it.

In January of 2006 Primitiva joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.

Primitiva is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her eighth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Francis Odhiambo

texts.en:
Francis O. is 29 years old and is from Kisumu city, Western Kenya. He is married to Lucy, who has a charcoal business, and they have a one-year-old child named Lenox. 

Francis runs a second-hand clothing business at Kibuye market, a large open air market just a few meters from the heart of Kismu city. He has been operating this business for the last six years and makes a monthly income of 8,000 KES. 

Francis is requesting his first loan from Kadet Ltd to buy a new stock of second-hand clothing. Second-hand clothing is cheaper and Francis anticipates making greater sales as the December festivities approach. Francis hopes to increase profits and expand his business to improve his family’s living standards by providing for their daily basic needs.

loans.use: to buy used clothing

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim S., 45, is a village woman living in Kompong Cham Province. She is a local crop farmer. She currently grows rice crop, vegetables, and some fruit on her own farmland. To help meet the family's daily expense needs, her husband helps her in the same business. This family can earn an income of at least $10 per day. They have five children, and all of them are single, still living under their roof. In the past time, Sim S. hired a plowing machine from her neighbor for plowing her farmland.  Now it is the time for paying for plowing her saving account is not enough to pay for. To solve this problem, Sim S. would like to borrow some fund from Kiva to pay for plowing cost and to buy some seeds for planting. Note: Sim S. and her husband are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To pay for plowing cost and to buy some seeds for planting.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 36-year-old single lady. She has run her beauty salon for the last six years, which earns her 20,000 Kenyan Shillings (KSH) monthly. Over this period she has been able to identify potential clients and gathered enough expertise to make her likely to excel. This is her first loan after being introduced to Kadet by friends who have been benefited from it. She plans to use the anticipated profits to fully equip her salon.

loans.use: buying equipment for her salon

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.ru: Сафаев Хусейн проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Ему 27 лет. Женат. Имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Хусейн не имеет высшего образования. Более 7 лет занимается торговлей. В поселке "Аскари сурх" он продает горючее. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. То есть он намерен в оптом купить солярку и бензин.
texts.en: Huseyn S. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 27 years old, married, and has one child.  His wife is a housewife.  Hussein does not have a higher education.  He has been working in sales for more than seven years. He sells fuel in the village Askari Surkh.  He is taking out a loan to increase sales.  He intends to buy diesel and gasoline wholesale.

loans.use: increasing sales

loans.name: Basilides

texts.en:
Basilides E. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 54 years old and married. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She sells noodles, soft drinks, toothpaste and other kinds of products.

She joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Basilides is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bebiana

texts.en:
Bebiana L. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 39 years old. Bebiana is married and has seven children. Her eldest child is 18 years old while the youngest is only 2 years old. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of making and selling banana ques and other delicacies. 

Bebiana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice K. is a 38-year-old married lady with five children. She operates a tailoring shop at Mjanaheri in Malindi town. She was introduced to KADET LIMITED by  one of the registered clients of Kadet. She is now taking her second loan of  Kshs.10,000, with which she plans to buy a modern sewing machine and materials that she will use to make dresses.  Beatrice hopes that, by doing this, her  business will grow and she will be able to use the anticipated profit to help expand the business even more so that one day she may get to own a boutique.

loans.use: to buy a modern sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Kyosimba Onaanya Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
50-year-old N. Hadijah is affliated with the Kyosimba-Onaanya Women's group in Lugazi, Uganda. For 13 years she has been engaged in a banana and sweet potato selling business in Buikwe. It is a business which in many ways compliments her farming activities in the sense that, unlike other people who buy foods to resell, she just sells what she harvests. 

This widowed mother of two comes across as a hardworking and good-natured woman. This business generates about $35 weekly, and with this loan Hadijah says she is going to rejuvenate her business. She is thinking about buying high grade manure for her farming gardens to improve her harvests, and also getting a permanent stall at a nearby market from which to operate her business.

loans.use: The purchase of high grade manure for her farming gardens

loans.name: Emerenciana

texts.en:
Emerenciana L. is a 58-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: pig raising and a general store. She lives in Proper, Brgy. Dungga, Danao City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,400. Emerenciana is now borrowing PHP 15,000 to use as additional working capital. This will be her 4th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Emerenciana hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Elpedio

texts.en:
Elpedio C. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 47 years old, married and has 5 children. His eldest child is 20 years old and the youngest is 10. Elpedio owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Elpedio has been planting and harvesting vegetables for almost 10 years and earns approximately PHP 3,000 per month.

Elpedio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elpedio is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.ru: Хайдарова Насиба проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 22 года. Не замужем. Образование среднее. Работает на рынке Дехкон. Арендует торговую точку, где продает парфюмерию и разную мелочь. Этим видом деятельности занимается 10 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Nasiba H. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 22 years old and single.  She has a high school education.  She works in the Dehkon market.  She rents a shop where she sells perfume and different knick-knacks.  She has been doing this work for ten years.  She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she carries.

loans.use: to increase the variety of goods she carries

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 38 years old, married and has 2 children aged 10 and 2. Gilda owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for breeding. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

Gilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda D. is a 39-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: fishing and food vending. She lives in Purok 2, Brgy. Pasil, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,500. Nilda is now borrowing PHP 19,000 so that she can continue to purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nilda hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team. "

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and equipment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine R. is a married woman who lives in Hda. Vallesteros, Brgy. Caradio-an, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: selling toddy and a general store. Her husband Elorde, 44 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 18 and 21 years old. Josephine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon and her own efforts, Josephine has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,500, thus raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her toddy and general store businesses so that she can continue to save up for her youngest son's future education and get a job. Josephine R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team. "

loans.use: to fund the operations of her toddy and general store businesses

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn B., from the town of Trinidad, is the 36-year-old married mother of four children aged 15, 13, 9 and 7. For over three years Jocelyn has operated a hog business, raising them for fattening and sale. She earns approximately 2000 PHP a month, working hard to sustain her children's education and dreaming that they finish college and have bright futures.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to buy additional piglets and feeds. Jocelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en:
Rubina E., 46 and married, supports her family by operating a farming business. A resident of Purok 3, Brgy. San Jose, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental, Rubina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable and now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000. Rubina is requesting Php 23,000 in order to continue to fund her farm operations. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rubina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her farm

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Prum C. is a 25-year-old woman living in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She has a good skill for making bamboo lattice-work used for flooring, and she often gets orders from the villagers who live near her house or from other provinces. She can make an income of on average $1.25 per day.

Prum C. has a life partner in her husband who works in a brick kiln as a machinery controller and has a proper salary every month so that he can share in covering daily expenses for the family. This couple has four children, all of whom are single, living at home. 

In order to earn more profit, Prum C. is applying for a loan from Kiva to purchase more bamboo to make lattices to sell and she hopes to buy oil for putting in machinery.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to make lattices and oil for machinery

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn has been dedicated since she’s obtained working capital to engage in  a hog-fattening business. Presently, she relies on this activity to cover her personal costs and help sustain her family. Jocelyn buys piglets from her neighbors, raises them, and when they have reached a good point of development, she sells them to business people who visit the village, either alive or slaughtered for their meat to be sold per kilo. This activity is very common in their place and many entrepreneurs do this.

Jocelyn wishes to expand her business by buying more piglets, vitamins, and feed for piglets, in order to forge ahead with her business and be able to help her family to get ahead. For this reason, she is, for the second time approaching KIVA lenders through ASHI, for a loan amounting to 20,000 Php to help her reach her goal.

Jocelyn is a hard-working woman dedicated to her home. Her dream is to care for her seven children and offer them a better quality of life, out of poverty. Jocelyn’s neighbors, friends and even her group mates consider her respectful person.

Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her hog-raising business, start a savings account for her children and support them to finish their studies until they complete college to get better careers someday.

With hard work and determination, Jocelyn is focused on improving her quality of life through her business efforts and support from ASHI and Kiva lenders across the world.

loans.use: To support her hog-raising business

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor D. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 52 years old. Victor is married and has a 22-year-old. To earn a living, Victor makes and sells "bahalina" (coconut wine) to his community. Victor says "bahalina" sells well in his town. He hopes to be able to expand his business, though, and get more customers. 

Victor joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victor has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Victor is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: investing in expanding the business

loans.name: Rodah Naliaka

texts.en:
Rodah Naliaka S. is a 54-year-old woman. She has five children who are all over 18. She buys maize and beans in bulk and sells them in small quantities. Rodah has been in this business for 10 years now and gets a monthly income of 20,000 shillings.

This will be Rodah's first loan from KADET, and she plans to use the entire loan to buy bags of maize and beans for resale. With the income she is going to get she plans to buy a farm so that she can plant maize and beans to sell. In the future, she wants to raise her family's standard of living and provide them with basic needs like food and shelter.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans for resale

loans.name: Lom

texts.en:
Mrs. Lom C. (shown in the photo with her loom), is a widow with one son and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home and the other two work in a garment factory. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Mrs. Lom C. has been a silk weaver since 1979. She has already asked for one Kiva loan, and now she is asking for another loan of $700 to purchase weaving materials for  her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her weaving business
